They are lower, lower, lower, middle, and higher.
At the top, there are three grades.
They are middling, lower, middle, and middle-upper.
There are two levels of patience.
It's up and down, up, and in the middle.
The highest worldly condition is the highest dharma.
The only category is up.
If these three classes are included, it's as explained at the beginning.
Venerable Suyo said.
"There are three classes of Nun.
They are lower, lower, lower, middle, and higher.
At the top, there are two classes.
They are middling, lower, and middle.
There are three levels of patience.
It's middle, upper, lower, upper, and middle.

source_sentence: 世第一法唯一品謂上上。
translation: The highest worldly dharma is the only class that's considered superior.
If we take these three classes and include them, then...
'Nun is only the lower level ...
The highest is only the middle rank.
The middle of patience is the higher grade.
The highest worldly dharma is only of the higher category.
Q What's the difference between these four good roots?
Answer: The classes explained differ.
That's a distinction.
Furthermore, there's also a difference in name.
This is called Nun.
... and this is called the highest worldly meditative state.
"Furthermore, this is the abode of mindfulness.
This is called Nun because it's equally and immediately recognizable.
The name for this is the summit of equal and indefinite warmth.
The top is equally and immediately preceded by the name ...
It's called forbearance.
Forbearance is equally uninterrupted.
It's called the highest worldly meditative state.
As such, it's equally and immediately applicable and has no indirect entry.
So it is with applied practices.
"Furthermore, delighting in separately contemplating the aggregates is called warmth.
Pleasantly observing the jewels separately is called pinnacle.
Delighting in separately contemplating the truth is called patience.
This gives rise to the highest worldly meditative state.
Furthermore, Nun stops folly in the lower part of the cognitive aspect.
At the top, it stops folly in regard to the middle of the noble truths.
Forbearance stops foolishness in regard to the higher of the truths.
This gives rise to the world's highest dharma.
Furthermore, Nun stops folly in regard to the crude aspect of conditioned truths.
He stops foolishness in the middle of the truths at the top.
He stops foolishness in regard to the subtle aspects of the tolerant aspects.
This gives rise to the world's highest dharma.
Furthermore, it's clear that Nun gives rise to the lesser of the conditional truths.
it's clarified that the truth of the conditioned aspect arises from the top ...
patience gives rise to the higher insight of the conditional truths.
This gives rise to the highest worldly truth.
Furthermore, it's clarified that Nun gives rise to the crude aspect of the conditioned truths ...
from the top arises the middle insight of the cognitive aspect.
patience gives rise to the subtle insight of the cognitive aspect of the truth.
As a result, the highest worldly truth arises.
As insight arises, so does faith arise.
This is called a distinction.
Among the wholesome roots that go along with the discriminating aspect, these are the distinctions.
Nun also attains and rejects them.
Attaining is because of applied practices.
Equanimity is sometimes due to regression.
It's sometimes due to transgressing the boundary ground.
Or it's because they abandon the many parts of the same thing.
After he gives up this Nun ...
He'll also do unremitting activity.
It also cuts off good roots.
They'll also fall into a bad destiny.
What's the superior benefit?
It can be a definitive cause of nirvāṇa?
It means he attains warmth.
He's like a fish that swallows a hook.
It's because he has attained the certainty of the state of nirvāṇa.
At the top, he also attains and rejects it.
Attaining it is because of applied practices.
Equanimity is sometimes due to retrogression ...
It might be because they've crossed the borderlands.
It might be because he's abandoning the common parts of all people.
After he gives up the crown, he also does unremitting karma.
'I'll also do unremitting activity.'
They'll also fall into a bad destiny.
What other surpassing benefit does it have?
It's the ability to end up not stopping the good roots.
Q If that's the case, then the gods should have granted him the top of the head before he attained it.
It's because they've developed wrong views that cut off their good roots.
What does Gatha say?
"What would be its penetration?
It's like they say.

source_sentence: 愚夫眾所識　　是名為失利
translation: 'This is called a loss of benefit when it's known by foolish people.'

source_sentence: 白法皆滅壞　　應知從頂墮
translation: all white dharmas are destroyed, and you should know that you are falling from the top.
"This is a verse the Bhagavān says.
It's spoken for the sake of divine empowerment.
"So it's a divine mandate.
After retreating from the top, he cut off his good roots.
He then cut off his good roots.
How then did he say.
'After I give up the top of my head, I won't stop being good.'
He mustn't stop being good.'
Answer: By relying on the fact that he hasn't yet retreated, he says he's fallen from the top.
"Devadatta.
'I've cultivated warmth.
He won't soon attain the top.
Because of this renown and benefit, he'll fall back and lose his Nun.

source_sentence: 復斷善根於頂應得而不得故。
translation: Because he has also cut off his good roots, he attains the summit but doesn't attain it.
He says the fall from the top is called not a retrogression from having attained it.
Some people say this.
'The Bhagavān thus peaked and did evil at the Buddha's expense.
He falls into a bad destiny.
That's why it's called falling from the [four] peaks.
There are other teachers who say the Buddha's teaching is like a crown.
They then corrupt the Buddha's teaching and fall back on their own.
That's why they're called 'falling from the pinnacle.'
Patience is also attained and abandoned.
Attaining it is because of applied practices.
Equanimity is attained either by transgressing the boundary ground or by abandoning the same part of the group.
It's also because they abandon the common parts of all people.
It's not because of retrogression.
"What other surpassing benefit does it have?
It's not regressing after all.
They won't do unremitting activity.
They won't fall into a bad destiny.
It's the highest worldly meditative state.
It's also attained and abandoned.
Attaining it is because of applied practices.
Equanimity is attained by transgressing the borderlands.
It's not because of regression.
Nor does it result from abandoning the common parts of all [sentient beings].
"What other surpassing benefit is there?
It's equally uninterrupted.
It's entering the true nature and escaping birth.'
There are other teachers who say.
'Nun also attains and rejects [renunciation] as explained above.'
After he [renounces] this Nun ...
He'll also create unremitting activity.
They'll also fall into a bad destiny.
What superior benefit is there?
Can it be a definite cause for nirvāṇa?
And can it ultimately stop producing good roots?
If that's the case, then the gods' mandate probably hasn't been given to Nun.
It's because they've developed wrong views and cut off their good roots.
The tipping point is also attained and abandoned as explained above.
After renouncing this tipping point, he'll also fall into a bad destiny.
What other surpassing benefit is there?
They won't do any unremitting activity.
Patience is also attained, and it's abandoned as explained above.
"What other surpassing benefit is there?
He doesn't regress after all.
They won't fall into a bad rebirth.
They don't cling to self.

source_sentence: 問若爾鄔波離室利毱多。
translation: Q. Suppose it's Upāliśālī and Gupta.
Should he point to the garlands and speak truly?
Shouldn't they have attained forbearance?
They cling to the existence of a self.
That's why they resist the Buddha.
Answer: They want to argue.
He nominally posits that there's a self.
They really don't cling to it.
It's the highest worldly meditative state.
He attains equanimity and so forth.
They're all as explained above.

source_sentence: 說一切有部發智大毘婆沙論卷第六
translation: Saṃyuktâgama Abhidharma-mahāvibhāṣā-śāstra, vol. 6
